definition:
Let ${\mathfrak{g}}$ be a finite dimensional semisimple Lie algebra. The
*nilpotent cone* ${\mathcal{N}}$ of ${\mathfrak{g}}$ is the set of
elements that act nilpotently in all representations of
${\mathfrak{g}}$. In other words,
$${\mathcal{N}}=\{ a\in {\mathfrak{g}}: \rho(a) \text{ is nilpotent for all representations } \rho:{\mathfrak{g}}\to \operatorname{End}(V)\}$$
The nilpotent cone is an of ${\mathfrak{g}}$ (considered as a $k$-vector
space), and is invariant under the adjoint action of ${\mathfrak{g}}$ on
itself.
remarks:
**Example:** if ${\mathfrak{g}}=\operatorname{sl}_2$, then the nilpotent
cone is the variety of all matrices in ${\mathfrak{g}}$ with rank $1$.
